title: 107_hr1621
content: The Act may be cited as the "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act of 2001" and includes findings and purposes. The Arabia Mountain area contains natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources that represent the heritage of the United States. Managing these resources through partnerships between public and private entities is the best approach. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve in DeKalb County, Georgia is a 535-acre park. Panola Mountain State Conservation Park in DeKalb County, Georgia protects granite outcrop ecosystems, wetlands, and federally-protected plant species. The park includes Panola Mountain, a rare example of a pristine granite outcrop, and the archeological site at Miners Creek Preserve shows evidence of early human activity. Lithonia, Arabia Mountain, and Stone Mountain in Georgia also have significant historical sites. Arabia Mountain and Stone Mountain in Georgia showcase the history of granite mining and its impact on the United States. Klondike is eligible for National Historic District designation, while Lithonia has 2 structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The Act aims to recognize, preserve, and promote the natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources in the area. The Act aims to develop and implement a cultural, historical, and land resource management program to protect and interpret significant resources within the heritage area that includes Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, Miners Creek, and other sites in Georgia. The Act defines key terms such as "heritage area," "management entity," "management plan," "Secretary," and "State" in relation to the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia. SEC. 4. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA. The Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area is established in the State, consisting of land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. A map of the area is available for public inspection, and the Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance will be the management entity. The Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area is established in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties with the Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance as the management entity. SEC. 5 outlines the authorities and duties of the management entity. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area has the authority to make grants, hire staff, and enter into contracts for goods and services. Their duties include developing and submitting a management plan to the Secretary. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area must consider the interests of various governmental, business, and nonprofit groups. They prioritize implementing actions from the management plan, such as assisting in resource preservation and promoting land use policies. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area must conduct public meetings quarterly and submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing accomplishments, expenses, and income. They are also required to undergo an audit. The management entity must provide records for audit of Federal funds and agreements with other organizations. They are prohibited from using Federal funds for unauthorized purposes. The management entity cannot use Federal funds from this Act to acquire real property. However, they can use Federal funds from other laws for authorized purposes. The management entity is prohibited from using Federal funds from this Act to acquire real property but can use funds from other laws for authorized purposes. The management entity must develop a management plan for the heritage area based on the preferred concept in the "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Feasibility Study". The plan should incorporate an integrated approach to protect, interpret, and enhance the natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources of the area, taking into consideration State and local plans, and involving residents, public agencies, and private organizations. The management plan for the heritage area must include an inventory of resources, assessment of cultural landscapes, and provisions for protection, interpretation, and management of the area. The management plan for the heritage area must include provisions for protection, interpretation, and enjoyment of resources, as well as an interpretation plan and a program for implementation that identifies sources of funding. The management plan for the heritage area must include provisions for protection, interpretation, and enjoyment of resources, as well as an evaluation of the management entity's structure and membership. The management entity must submit the plan to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of the Act's enactment. Failure to submit the plan will result in no additional funding from the Secretary. The Secretary will not provide additional funding until a management plan for the heritage area is submitted. Within 90 days of receiving the plan, the Secretary will approve or disapprove it in consultation with the State. If the plan is disapproved, it must be revised. The Secretary must advise the management entity in writing of reasons for disapproval, make recommendations for plan revisions, and allow the entity to submit revisions. Within 90 days of receiving a revision, the Secretary must approve or disapprove it. After approval of a management plan by the Secretary, the management entity must periodically review and submit recommendations for any revisions to the plan. No funds under this Act can be used to implement a revision without approval from the Secretary within 90 days. The management entity must submit proposed revisions to the management plan for approval by the Secretary before implementation under this Act. SEC. 7. TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. The Secretary may provide technical and financial assistance to heritage areas for developing and implementing management plans, prioritizing actions that conserve natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources, as well as providing educational and recreational opportunities consistent with the area's values. Authorization of $10,000,000 for the Act, with a limit of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. Federal share not to exceed 50%. Secretary's grant authority terminates on September 30, 2016.
